posts.name: Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked:
Hello!

Our team has been facing power supply issues with our Raspberry Pi 5. We were initially using a Pololu step-down converter, but when I drove the bot, we experienced voltage drops, causing the Pi to lose power temporarily. We are now considering purchasing an individual power supply and are looking at the INIU 100W Power Bank. Here’s the link:

INIU 100W Power Bank on Amazon

We’d appreciate your feedback on whether this power bank would be a suitable solution. The 100W output should definitely suffice, as the Pi only requires 5V at 5A (25W).

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: INIU 100W Power Bank, Mini Size 25000mAh High Capacity Laptop Portable Charger, USB C in&Out Tablet Powerbank, Smart Digital Display Phone Charger for iPhone 16 15, Samsung, iPad, MacBook, Laptop etc. : Cell Phones & Accessories

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
the raspberry pi 5 uses a nonstandard (or at least not commonly implemented) usb-c configuration: most sources can’t make 5a using 5v.

we use the redux zinc regulator with our pi 5s, they work great.

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
SamEthanMathew:

We are now considering purchasing an individual power supply and are looking at the INIU 100W Power Bank.

Since it seems that this is a robot part, it is subject to R602 , which permits only “ COTS USB battery packs with a capacity of 100Wh or less (27000mAh at 3.7V) with 5V/5A max output or 12V/5A max output using USB-PD per port”. Do you have enough information to comply with this portion of the rule? Where is it documented, and will you be able to show it to a robot inspector?

A lot of USB devices will use 20 V (or more) to provide their power rating. 5 A is not always implemented.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
@SamEthanMathew

Hint…scroll down to the reviews for some of this critical information.

posts.name: Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked:
The battery gives out 100W and the pi only needs 5V 5A so that’s 25W. There’s different ports on the battery limiting the power one of them being 45W. Since the pi only takes what it needs this would still be considered legal I assume?

Regarding rule 602 it states no batteries over 100W. I’m not sure if I’m calculating this right but the capacity of the battery is 25000mah. The pi needs 5V so that’s 125W? (25000*5/1000) Could someone clarify? Thank you so much!

posts.name: Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked: If you don’t mind me asking what do you connect to the pi? As of now we plan on running four camera’s off of one pi and we use it for April cam detection and driver cam.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
This year, we’re using one Raspberry Pi global shutter camera per Raspberry Pi 5 CPU, used for AprilTag detection.  We’re using 3.2 mm lenses, which provide a horizontal field-of-view of about 90 degrees.  The detector runs at full resolution (1440x1080), and so it can see tags 10 meters away, but also as close as about 20 cm.

We have five cameras on the robot, so we have five Raspberry Pi 5’s.  We tried multiple cameras per CPU, but, unsurprisingly, that reduced the frame rate proportionally, and we wanted to maximize frame rate.  With fan cooling, we get around 50 fps per camera, with end-to-end latency of something like 80 ms.

Overall I’m pretty happy with this setup, with the exception of the ribbon cable between the pi and the camera, which leads to packaging headaches.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Your calculations are correct from a POWER perspective, and it being a 100WH battery does pass R602 But…

Not all USB-C devices can provide that amount of POWER at lower voltage levels.

In the case of your linked device: it can only make 3A at 5V on any given port.

So the 45W port achieves that marketing value of 45W via the 15V@3A negotiated power level. Because the Pi does not negotiate USB-PD and only takes the default 5V but at 5A, this battery will only be able to supply 5V@3A or 15W.

image 1570×1050 149 KB

image 1570×1050 149 KB

image 1570×1050 149 KB

Separately, R602 line 2 mentions “…5V/5A max output or 12V/5A max output”…the selected power bank CAN do 15V and 20V levels which I read as violating R602

posts.name: Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked: I see. One of the teams I talked to have used this power source to power their orange pi. So I think if we connected it to the 100W outlet, we would be fine, right?

posts.name: Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked: My concern is that a redux wont be enough since we will be using one pi to power four camera’s so I’m not sure if it would have enough power.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Technically speaking: the orangePi and RPi5 MAY run just fine on this power source, but if you are running 4 cameras or otherwise asking those devices to do a heavy workload they may try to pull power that isn’t there and then crash or behave unexpectedly. Your Mileage May Vary (YMMV).

FIRST Legal? In 2024 I would have said YES because there was a Q&A question that answered along the lines of: if you can prove your device wont put out more than 5V when installed and connected then its legal. And that was trivial to prove as the orange Pi and RPi5 document that they ONLY power via 5V (at either 4-5A respectivly).

But this year with changes to R602 I do NOT read the linked supply as LEGAL because of the 12V max OUTPUT per PD port requirement. The device you linked CAN do 15V or 20V, which are >12V.

R602 as of 3/13/25

*Other batteries for cameras or computers only. COTS USB battery packs with a capacity of 100Wh or less (27000mAh at 3.7V) with 5V/5A max output or 12V/5A max output using USB-PD per port, batteries integral to and part of a COTS computing device or self-contained camera (e.g. laptop batteries, GoPro style camera, etc.), or batteries used to power CMOS/RTC features may be used to power COTS computing devices and any peripheral COTS input or output devices connected to the COTS computing device provided they are: A. securely fastened to the ROBOT, B. connected only using unmodified COTS cables, and C. charged according to manufacturer recommendations. A COTS computing device is a non-roboRIO device used to process or collect sensor information (e.g. a “smart flashlight” is not a COTS computing device). "

posts.name: Jason Evans
posts.cooked:
Our team is just about to get Pololu step-down converters integrated after two different other kinds failing to provide consistent output. The Pololu ones have been recommended on ChiefDelphi, and their specs suggest they should work very well for powering Pi 5s.

This is the first report I’ve seen of Pololus not working well. Can you provide some details re: battery voltage when you experienced failure, and anything else that might be relevant, like wire gauge, camera model, and Pi 5 model? If we are likely to suffer the same issue, I’d like to start executing contingency plans ASAP.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked:
We are using a 5V 9A pololu stepdown regulator. Link: Pololu 5V, 9A Step-Down Voltage Regulator D24V90F5

We used an 18AWG power wire, which is powered by the PDH with a 20A Fuse, which connected to the pololu and using this wire we connected it to the pi5. We use this arducam and we have four of them connected to the pi (two for driver cam and two for CV).

The Pololu works fine, but when we increase the speed of our bot, there’s a higher voltage drop that the pololu is not able to manage.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: USB C to 2 Pin Bare Wire Open End Power Cable 3FT, 20AWG 5V USB Type C Male Plug 2 Pin Pigtail Cable, for USB Type C Equipment Installed or Replacement Repair DIY Cable(2Pcs) : Electronics
Amazon.com: Arducam 8MP IMX179 USB Camera Module, Wide Angle Lightburn Camera, USB Security Camera with 115°(H) M12 Lens, Single Microphone for Windows, Linux, Android, and Mac OS : Electronics

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
yeah, maybe.  i don’t know anything about USB cameras.

it’s surprising that the 1v dropout voltage of the pololu D24V90 would be a problem, since it implies you’re driving its supply down to 6v, and at that point, the roborio brownout protection would probably be active.

posts.name: Sam Ethan Mathew
posts.cooked: Our team is just as confused. We initially thought it was a heat regulation issue, but our pololu had enough ventilation to cool down (I will share pictures later today from the lab). Not sure what to do now. We bought a secondary battery from Pishop, and it seems to work well, but it’s out of stock now, and we modified the charging wire for it (modified the charging wire so it could be powered by the FRC battery, but it goes against R602B). Link to the product: 5v5a pishop battery

link_counts.title: Uninterruptible Power Supply Module, Supports charging And Power output at the same time, 3S & 5V 5A Output - PiShop.us

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Is it possible to plug the cameras into a powered USB hub which would then plug into the coprocessor? This would allow the power for the coprocessor to be supplied by one DC-DC converter and the power for the cameras to be supplied by a second DC-DC converter through the USB hub. The power for the cameras would no longer flow through the coprocessor.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Although this will lower the load on the original DC-DC I don’t think that is their problem.

Redux Robotics has measured the OrangePi5 with 1 camera running photonvision to pull ~1.5A @5V DC.

That puts the dropout on their selected DC-DC around 0.75V DC, meaning it should hold its output @5V as long as the input stayed above 5.75V DC.

On other threads recently people have measured the outputs of a PDH to be in the 8V-10V range under a 150A drivetrain transient load.

@SamEthanMathew I would check the wiring and ensure any solder joints or splice points (i.e. using a crimp splice or WAGO busbar), are well formed, stripped to the correct lengths, and making good contact. The devices you linked should work well together - although I would lower to a 5A breaker or 10A fuse per table 8-4 of R622 because of your 20AWG USB-C wire - or add an output fuse on an 18awg wire before stepping down to 20awg.

After checking solder connections and splice joints…I would check which terminals of the DC-DC are you actually using as the output?

This picture shows you could be using the smaller 4-pin terminal on the long side of the board with Vout…make sure Vout is actually the larger terminals on the opposite short side of VIN. The smaller Vout is for small logic-level stuff with a small trace which could have a large voltage drop under significant load.

image 1050×477 77.1 KB

image 1050×477 77.1 KB

image 1050×477 77.1 KB

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I’m also suspect of the selected DC-DC saying it dynamically switches the buck-switcher frequency to optimize I/O power efficiency. I would hope the 5V output doesn’t see a significant hiccup during this change in converter switching frequency, but if it does that power blip may be resetting the co-proc.

The only way to rule this out/test this would be to hook up an Oscilloscope and look at the output voltage as well as the switcher frequency while varying the input voltage - an involved process.

I am more suspicious of your wiring connections all being good though - too many times have I seen cold solder joints or wires not inserted enough into a WAGO that checking the wiring is my first step.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
All DC-DC converters have some energy storage capacity. DC-DC converters with higher output current ratings will have greater energy storage capacity.

Connecting a DC-DC converter to a load with a maximum current draw that is only a fraction of it’s rated output current capacity will have the effect of increasing the ride-through time when there is a disruption of the input voltage.

Thus, splitting the loads gives one more options for finding DC-DC-converters rated so that the load is only a fraction of the rating.

Jwal:

I’m also suspect of the selected DC-DC saying it dynamically switches the buck-switcher frequency to optimize I/O power efficiency. I would hope the 5V output doesn’t see a significant hiccup during this change in converter switching frequency, but if it does that power blip may be resetting the co-proc.

The only way to rule this out/test this would be to hook up an Oscilloscope and look at the output voltage as well as the switcher frequency while varying the input voltage - an involved process.

I am more suspicious of your wiring connections all being good though - too many times have I seen cold solder joints or wires not inserted enough into a WAGO that checking the wiring is my first step.

Yes. This is a possibility and it probably happens more often than we realize. I had to fix one that would spike on turn-on and blow up half of the boards connected to it.

At the relatively low current levels relevant here, the wiring would have to be really bad to cause enough voltage drop to be a significant factor.
